verses.text: Keep me safe, O God, for in you I take refuge.
I said to the LORD, "You are my Lord; apart from you I have no good thing."

rsbNotes.title: Ps 16
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 16 This psalm expresses confidence in the Lord, though it is difficult to tell whether the crisis is past or present to the psalmist. Death may be imminent for him (v. 10).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 16:1
rsbNotes.text: 16:1 An invocation of the Lord and a plea for help. This line indicates that the crisis is still present to the psalmist.

verses.text: As for the saints who are in the land, they are the glorious ones in whom is all my delight.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 16:3
rsbNotes.text: 16:3 saints. Lit. “those who are set apart,” God’s elect people.

verses.text: The sorrows of those will increase who run after other gods. I will not pour out their libations of blood or take up their names on my lips.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 16:4
rsbNotes.text:
16:4 another god. The danger of worshiping other gods was always present in Israel (cf. 1 Kin. 18). The psalms emphasize that the powers and epithets ascribed to the pagan gods really belong to Yahweh (Ps. 29).

offerings of blood . . . names. That is, of foreign gods. These are two examples of ways that the religious systems of the surrounding nations tried to compel their gods to help them.

verses.text: LORD, you have assigned me my portion and my cup; you have made my lot secure.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 16:5
rsbNotes.text: 16:5 portion . . . cup . . . lot. Three metaphors that describe life as a gift of God.

verses.text: The boundary lines have fallen for me in pleasant places; surely I have a delightful inheritance.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 16:6
rsbNotes.text: 16:6 lines. Once again, probably metaphoric for the psalmist’s quality of life. Not only is the life that God has given him secure (v. 5), it is also “pleasant.”

verses.text: I will praise the LORD, who counsels me; even at night my heart instructs me.
I have set the LORD always before me. Because he is at my right hand, I will not be shaken.
Therefore my heart is glad and my tongue rejoices; my body also will rest secure,

rsbNotes.title: Ps 16:7
rsbNotes.text: 16:7 heart. Lit. “kidneys” (text note). Like “heart,” it stands for the core of a person’s being.

verses.text: because you will not abandon me to the grave, nor will you let your Holy One see decay.
You have made known to me the path of life; you will fill me with joy in your presence, with eternal pleasures at your right hand.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 16:10
rsbNotes.text: 16:10 you will not abandon my soul to Sheol. The immediate application of this psalm is to David and to the Old Testament saints. It refers to deliverance from the immediate threat of death, but it points prophetically to the Son of David whom the historical David reflected and anticipated. Both Peter and Paul recognized that Jesus was the ultimate fulfillment of this psalm (Acts 2:25–28; 13:35).
